page.title: 06Traces of Cornish language
page.content: Evidence of the Cornish language here is mostly confined(to place names,farm names and field names)."parc",Cornish for field exists in such names as 'Downpark,Crosspark,Bramblepark'.The prefix 'Tre','Pol','Pen'is prolific in the area-'Tre'-house or homestead Trewiddle,Trevissick,Tregorrick, Trenarren,'Pol'-pool,the farm named Polgase is directly from the language 'glas' meaning 'blue' hence blue pool and 'Pen'-headland-Pentewan.Nansladron occurs in the origional Doomsday Survey-Nans-a valley 'Ladron' of thieves.Other place names are Duporth -'du' black/dark beach,Porthpean-small beach or cove-'byghan'the'gh'is soft means small.Names such as Menagwins- Men-stone-gwyn-white refers to cornish granite-whitestone probably a Menhir & Mulvra'bald hill'.
